The words gluttony and greed come to mind. So, my lesson for you, the reader, in this review, is please try to not overeat during your visit here. It not hard to do!

Very much a touristy thing to do, but that doesn't make it any less awesome.  The Deep Sea Tasting Room is on the harbor, which is a good place to have a SB experience.  The wine, albeit, is not amazing.  The prices are average, but I have not been impressed by the flights.  I'd recommend getting a glass of your fave, in order to avoid tasting some not-so-good wines.  However, the staff here is super friendly and you can't beat the view!  I wish they had more/better furniture in the outdoor patio.  But, really I am just nitpicking - go to Deep Sea Tasting Room if you enjoy sipping wine with an ocean view.  And who doesn't?

If you could go to one tasting place in Santa Barbara, I'd recommend this one!  Although I love Kalyra wines, I think this place is fun because they have so much of a variety, with wine and beer flights.  They have a traditional beer tastings, as well as fruit beers.  You can apply the flight price to your wine/beer purchase, which is always a plus.  

The flights are pretty affordable (normal for the area), with a range of options for different prices (i.e., chardonnay/white tastings are cheaper than some cab/red tastings).  

This is the best place to take a group, even if they are newbies to the wine/beer tasting world.  The location is great - take a walk along the coast after you taste!

The only reason I give this place four stars instead of five, is because the staff weren't the friendliest.  Not rude, but not nice and welcoming either.  But I've only been here once, so maybe next time my experience with the staff would be different.

Yes, we are health freaks, but really... they have probably the best burgers and fries I've had.  I rarely eat red meat... let alone with a side of deep-fried potatoes... but I will stretch to make excuses to eat here ("I was in Vegas all weekend and still need to soak up the alcohol.... I went to the gym everyday this week, my body probably needs protein...").  Hey, I didn't say they were good excuses.\n\nI tried the turkey burger once, which is usually my go to if I'm craving a burger... but I say, splurge for the classic cheeseburger and fries.  This is a once-a-year treat, but so worth the wait!

Only been here once last fall, but I guess it's not really my scene.  The drinks were pretty strong and on the pricey side.  I think the music was alright, and the inside and outside look pretty cool aesthetically.  The night I was there, it was mostly people lounging and talking, no dancing.  I didn't have to pay a cover, so maybe we got there early.  But I don't think I'd ever return, because I'd rather have a more friendly, cozy place with seating like The Neighborhood, or a place to dance.  There's better places in Santa Barbara.

Love the concept of this place, love the food even more.

The bf and I shared a Backyard Bowl for a Saturday afternoon snack.  The fruit was fresh, the bee pollen was sweet, the goji berries were chewy, the granola was crunchy, and the blended smoothie part was refreshing.  Just a perfect, perfect combination of fresh, (mostly) organic and local foods.  It is a little pricey, but you get what you pay for... and it's definitely worth it!  I want to go back and try the other bowls... but you have to be careful with calories on these.  Although it sounds and tastes healthy, I think it's better to share a bowl unless it's your lunch (forgive me, I'm on a calorie-counting kick right now).

I also really like this location.  A walk from the major shops downtown, and there is an open-walled outdoor area to eat and enjoy the Santa Barbara breeze.

I love this farmer's market!  It's tucked away in a street a couple blocks from downtown.  There's always a musician or two lightening the mood, as well as the balloon animal maker.  

My favorites:

*Autumn - grape stand, especially the lychee grapes and big, crunchy grapes
*Winter - persimmons, sugar snap peas, carrots
*Spring/Summer - all stone fruits!  
*Year-round - bread

Yes, prices are pretty high relative to other places in California, but normal for Santa Barbara.

Would have been a 4 star rating EXCEPT the cashier "forgot" to give our order ticket to the chefs in the back. We waited 20+ minutes for our 2 order of sushi as we watched numerous customers get their orders even though the ordered after us. (however, we were comped 2 free fountain drinks but i only drink water so it didn't matter!)

With that said, the sushi was pretty good! We had the Dragon roll combination which was a HUGE roll with these weird fishy flakes on top (which i didn't like that much). There was plenty of avocado and eel in each bite. Warning: it's kinda hard to eat because of the size and may get a little messy.

Our other dish was the California and Spicy Tuna roll combination plate. You get a TON of sushi (8 pieces of each) and the presentation is pretty cool. 

Overall, a pretty good sushi experience for an 'express' restaurant.

Thanks Cat Cora for the recommendation.  Casey and I have ventured up the mountains of Santa Barbara to satisfy our tri-tip craving two or three times now, ever since hearing about this place.  On the weekends (and I think just Sundays during non-summer months), they do their famous tri-tip sandwiches that you order in the bar (pay attention, because it's not obvious to figure out), and then you take your sandwich ticked up to the grill.  They give you a hefty portion of tri-tip laid on an oh-so melt-in-your-mouth roll.  There's a couple sauces and au jus to choose from.  And then you eat.  Perfection.  There are plenty of places to sit outside, accompanied by several biker dudes/chicks.  Great place to go if you're visiting SB or if you live in SB and have visitors (carnivores).
Umm, cashiers are NOT nice, I retract!  Zero stars for you, Kmart.

Perfect place for a quintessential Santa Barbara meal!  The location of this restaurant is right on the pier.  I wish the view was a bit better out the windows.  I would have sat outside but it was pretty cold that day.  We went around 2pm, so the wait was only about 10-15 minutes.  And we were able to watch the chef butcher and steam some massive crabs while we waited, quite entertaining!\n\nWe went with the coveted clam chowder and the cioppino in a bread bowl, along with some beers.  The ideal Santa Barbara meal!  Service was great, and food was quality.  A great place to bring a (small) group of visitors who want the Santa Barbara seafood experience, without the super high price tags.

Almost as visually pleasing and relaxing as the beach.  The architecture is just beautiful, parking is easy, and the view is breathtaking.  I'd like to take advantage of the thick patches of grass for some reading pleasure or a picnic.  And I'm going to bring any guest that comes to Santa Barbara to the clock tower view.  Ahhh, bliss.

Went today for the opening and was very pleased!  They advertised a noon opening, hyping it up by passing out flyers downtown last weekend.  They said there would be freebies for the first 250 customers.  I didn't really want to wait in a long line for a clothing store that I could find on weekend trips to LA, but when I was downtown today and the line to get in the store wasn't long, I decided to give it a shot.  They were giving everybody $10 off coupons for $50 purchases.\n\nI expected the worse as I entered the store... I thought it'd be a mess.  But it was one of the best organized, cleanest, neatest H&M's I've visited... and there were SOO many people!  So that shows that this staff has it down from the beginning.  Very impressed.  The space is pretty big, and there are a lot of clean dressing rooms.  Yay for H&M finally coming to Santa Barbara!

Uhhh seriously?  I'm shocked at the high reviews.  I will flat out say from the get-go... we are Yogurtland fanatics, so all yogurt places are held up to the Yogurtland standard.

-The price: relatively expensive compared to Yogurtland (Yogurtland is 30 cents an ounce, this place is 38 cents an ounce).

-The yogurt: not firm at all, didn't have the right tart flavor... totally was melting at a faster rate than normal.

-The toppings: meh.  Nothing special.  The fruit was not particularly fresh, and the dry toppings were similar to most joints.

-The service: fine.  Nothing extraordinarily good or bad.

Two stars, because why go here when we could go to Yogurtland?  It's even worth the drive.  Won't be returning, not worth the money.

Our experience was lackluster to say the least. The waitress got the wrong orders and repeatedly ignore our request to change it. she kept asking, "do you want more coke?" when she passes by. 

looking at other table getting the food they ordered, and savoying each bite as they chow down those juicy meat, kept us wondering: "what if we got what we wanted to eat?"

yes, this is a rustic tavern, enough said.
Best followup in this space so far. Unlike their predecessors, they seem to "get it" in many ways. A great addition to the scene on 10th and for Cummins Station.

Meh? These guys have a great location and a lot of potential but I was totally not impressed today. I ordered the orange chicken which was very chewy and dry. It came on broccoli which was barely steamed and cold. All the tables were sticky, and my tray was served with a previously used paper menu sheet, which might've just been beat up because he was placed on a wet tray. I didn't feel like there were any health problems in the place but it definitely doesn't stand up very well when you have superior options, both independently owned and nationally owned.

Holy HELL, the disorganized dumbfuckery here... It would be one thing if they were even remotely busy, or if it were just something like a language barrier but in general they seem to have an overall flawed process and trouble paying attention to what's going on. Having soy sauce locked up like Ft. Knox and then shoving a fist full at me wastefully makes no sense and just shows off the poor planning and lack of thinking involved.
Nice spot, and very well-located for all types of visitors, from daytime office traffic to the many residents of the Gulch. Nice to see them come to Nashville.

Phenomenal spot. Feels like a secret hideaway, loaded with history, excellent reuse of an old space. Good cocktail menu. Variety of party size accommodations. It can be crowded at times and a little hipster-dominated, but always a nice time.

Incredibly sexy spot for a date. If she's not impressed by this place, you call her a ride and lose her number. The mood and vibe are an ideal precursor for that "go back to my place" or "let's get a room" stage of the evening.

Good sound system and usually a good DJ working. It can get loud and the staff can be a little overrun, but a little confidence and good tipping goes a long way.

There are a few knowledgeable Nashville go-to locations for all manner of booze, and one of the best is Midtown. Large selection and good staff. Plenty of options for helpful attention to custom orders and such as well. Reasonable pricing and convenient location, with decent parking.
Tasty fare and a nice addition to the Nashville food landscape. Awkward location to drive to. Try to do a rideshare or walk up.

Ok, I'm in St. Louis on a business trip, what to do for dinner? Hooters?  Nah, not really interested in wings and orange short-shorts.  How about some ribs?  I stumbled on Masterpiece and got pulled in by the smells, who can resist ribs?  Order at the counter and grab a table, within 10 minutes I'm greeted with a large slab of ribs over white bread along with a side of cheese bread and baked beans.  \n\nOverall Masterpiece made some good ribs but not great.  A bit drier than I expected, I'm guessing they were sitting outside for a while.  Sides were ok but nothing to write home about, nothing particularly fresh.  I do enjoy my KC Masterpiece BBQ sauce at home but can't really say that you've got to try the place when visiting St. Louis.  There are probably better and more authentic rib joints in the city.  But I have to admit, the Gateway Arch on the walk back to the hotel was VERY cool....
Great breakfast! Kid friendly. Under 7 are charged a penny per pound to eat!  Really friendly staff and excellent food!

I was back in the St. Louis area visiting family and a very good friend took me to this place.  Let me say. WOW- I was very impressed by this place, the place looks amazing. Friendly fast service and the Alsatian - Vermont Crème Fraiche, Smoked Bacon, Caramelized Onions & Dante Cheese wood oven pizza was really amazingly delectable. \n\nIf and when I ever come back to BelleVegas--- I must dine here.

When I lived in St. Louis I loved this place, in fact I came here for another going away party with 12 or more people and we all had a wonderful time.

I no longer love this place. I came here a few weeks ago when I was in town for work and upon arrival the hostesses gruff attitude and hurried personality already rubbed me wrong.  The server a blond woman perhaps in her middle 30's early 40's simply was not as personable or enjoyable I was hoping she would be. She was inattentive and it seemed that waiting on us was a chore.

The food just didnt seem to be of high quality and lacked the flavor and creativity it once had. The Scallops were unbelievably small I guess I am use to large scallops I often see here on the East Coast. I will give them kudos to preparing them correctly. The Lobster was ok, and the shrimp was nothing exciting.
Disappointed in Modesto.
Nothing pleases a girl more than finding out that there's an Arby's directly beside her hotel.  And, that it's open killer late!!

If you're looking to scoot away from the touristy area of New Orleans, Morrow's is definitely a place to go.  When my friend and I arrived, we were told it would be 45 minutes for a table.  They don't take reservations.  Fortunately, we were able to snag two seats at the bar.  The service was friendly.  We were seated between two locals that struck up conversation and gave us recommendations on things to do and places to go.  

The food was good, albeit delivery was slow.  Real slow.  It took over 30 minutes to get a cup of gumbo, and over an hour to get our oysters.  The oysters were worth the wait.  So delicious (we got the charbroiled ones).  Drinks and prices were on point.  

Great dinner spot before venturing over to Frenchman for some local jazz.

Cool concept, but unfortunately it lacks any creative execution.  Lots of pancakes to choose from.  I don't really like pancakes though, so was stuck getting some bacon and eggs.  I'd say the food quality compared to that you'd get at IHOP or Waffle House.  My meal came with some pancakes on the side.  I got the banana bread ones.  They were decent, but far from amazing.  Actually, I could have made them at home.  \n\nThis place is overhyped and not really worth the wait.  Also, they don't offer anything but basic coffee and juice out of a carton to drink.  This is a typical diner, which happens to offer a million different combinations of pancakes.  I wouldn't go out of my way to return.

Craving noodles in Reno, and there was basically one option, Minato Noodles.

I got the Tonkotsu noodles, which was surprisingly brothy and delicious. Nothing was overseasoned, and takoyaki was also delicious.

My only gripe would be the toppings in the ramen. My egg was not soft-boiled nor marinaded. There was a singular bamboo piece. And the pork was pretty thin, as far as Chasu goes. 

Also, to add ANY additional topping it is 2 dollars. They need to differentiate some of the prices, as I really don't want to be paying 2 dollars for half a hard-boiled egg, or a couple pieces of bamboo. The only additional topping that it warranted being 2 dollars was the Chasu, which was also pushing it.

Still, great place for ramen, I wouldn't order any add-ons.

This was by far one of my favorite places on my recent trip to New Orleans.  Our sweet bartender at dba overheard that I was a vegetarian and suggested my friend and I try it out.  The atmosphere is quaint, cute, and comfortable. It helped that we stopped by on a local artists showcase night.  I'll tell you, I never expected the best country voice I've heard live to come out of a scruffy looking hipster!  Service was very slow as it seemed they were running with two bartenders and no servers, but luckily the atmosphere and being on vacation cured any impatience I had.  

As far as food goes, our ceviche was delicious.  We also ordered the butternut ravioli with brown butter... which was lacking.  I didn't expect the ravioli to be sitting in an entire inch bath of brown butter and would have much preferred a light brush of it.  Overall though, I really enjoyed the selection and the tapas style dishes because who doesn't like sharing?

Frenchman was definitely my favorite area of Nola and Three Muses is a running contender for number one on that block.

We went to Gennaro's last week for the first time, because I had been told they have a really great outdoor patio.  My husband, daughter and I brought a friend who was visiting from the West Coast.  The server was really nice. Her and the mosaic covered patio were probably the best part of Gennaro's.  

As someone noted in another review, they don't have high chairs here. It seems rather odd considering its an average quality pizza place. Luckily, our daughter is tall enough not to need one, but I wouldn't have been super excited if I had a younger child. Also, the front door has a sign saying something along the lines of "Well behaved children are welcome." Ok Gennaro's, you aren't that great. Your pizza is a few steps above Pizza Hut.  The POPE is a pub up the street that is very welcoming to kids. Le Virtu is a pretty high end restaurant up the street that is very welcoming to kids. I can't imagine childless people are showing up in droves at Gennaro's when there is Brigantessa almost directly across the street (which by the way also has high chairs.)

Also, they served out food with paper plates. Seriously. We ended up paying over $50 for pretty bland pizza, super dry foccacia bread, and their version of sangria. And we ate it off of paper plates!

So all in all, it was ok. I don't imagine we would go there again considering there is much better pizza available at much more child friendly places in the area.  But if you want to sit outside on a really pretty and shady patio and aren't worried about having the "best" pizza, it would probably serve your needs.

One of the best freshest Rock Crab I've ever had in my life. 

It was a late late late dinner. Did I mention how late we came in? We came 45 minutes before closing because we got to Santa Barbara late. The place is just 4 minutes car ride from where we stayed. 

When we came in, the place is almost packed and we proceeded to the corner booth.

So we ordered the Rock Crab and my wife ordered the Cioppino. What the hell is a Cioppino? For those of you who don't know a Cioppino, it's seafood chowder on steroid on a sourdough bread. And a side order of Onion Ring.

As we waited for our dinner, I noticed people still coming in until closing time.

When I ordered the crab, I was afraid not being able to finish them all. Well I was wrong... and full at the same time :)

Rock Crab came out fresh with a side of butter.

Cioppino was just a complete massive dish by itself

Gigantic Onion Rings to top our dinner off.

I was full, sleepy and felt guilty for staying almost an hour past their last call. As I paid our bill, I apologize for staying late. The waiter was all smile and said not to worry. 

As we got ready to leave, we realized that we were the last one in the restaurant and the last one in the entire pier...

Does Angry Chair have the most comfortable tap room in town where you want to sit for hours sampling the entire tap list? Nope. Are you guaranteed to find a wide variety of styles that will satisfy everyone in your party? Nope. Is parking plentiful and easy? Nope. Can you growler the more coveted varietals? Usually not.

So in spite of all this, what is the appeal? Simply put Angry Chair makes some of the best beers in the country. Whether you're looking for a mouth puckering sour or a dense pastry stout, Angry Chair can and does knock it out of the park. Producing some of the most flavorful and unique barrel-aged beers I've ever tried, Angry Chair sets the beer game bar high. Burkitshi, an Imperial Sweet stout with cacao, toasted coconut, and Japanese sea salt remains one of my penultimate favorites, rich and laden with flavor it reminds me of an Almond Joy. Another winner, Barrel Aged Popinski with Peanut Butter & Marshmallow tastes like a fluffernutter. A bottle we got lucky enough to enough to happen upon by pure happenstance, Bourbon Barrel Dave's Barleywine, had an excellent malt backbone and tasted like toffee.

The taproom itself is trendy and industrial, with cool metal bone seats that are more decorative than comfortable. Funky art scattered about, and of course the many references to "angry" chairs make for a laid back atmosphere. While by no means a spots bar, they do have a couple of televisions as well should you want to watch the game with a cold brew. Be warned though, the space itself isn't particularly large, so it may not be the best spot for a big group (although occasionally you can snag one of the coveted few more sizable tables).

While unfortunately I don't live close enough to synchronize my visits for every release, Angry Chair is my "must do" brewery every time I'm in Tampa, just in the hopes that I will strike the jackpot and pop in when they've just released something sinfully delicious. If it isn't already on your brewery bucket list make sure to put it near the top, Angry Chair produces the kind of stuff that both well seasoned beer geeks and novice drinkers will dream about.

A girl walks into a bar right as a band prepares to play, and goes to take a look at the drink menu. Vintage and seasonal cocktail options? Check. Interesting ingredients (like eucalyptus or Thai spice bitters)? Check. Then the music starts, upbeat and jazzy, and it feels fitting for the French Quarter. So she decides she should order a drink...

Quite some time later and I must admit, I was sold on 21st Amendment at La Louisiane. The drinks are solid, the atmosphere is lively without being raucous, and the music is exquisite. While it is a more intimate venue, seating routinely becomes available as the crowd ebbs and flows, making it a comfortable spot to hang out for a spell. 

Come with friends, come for a date, or come alone just to hang out at the bar, indulge in a cocktail, and enjoy the performance. 21st Amendment at La Louisiane offers a seductive scene with the winning ingredients to make a delightful night out in The Big Easy.

A small city unto itself, Gaylord Opryland is a sight to behold on par with some of the larger resorts in Las Vegas. A conference center and hotel, Gaylord Opryland offers ample walking paths, multiple restaurants, a river boat ride, a salon and spa, and now a water park as well. It is quite the labyrinth and is easy to get lost despite the signposts peppered throughout, although this often makes for the best exploration. While the hotel isn't located in the heart of downtown Nashville, it isn't a terribly far drive either.

Taking a stroll through the atriums is like being in a tropical oasis. There are multiple waterfalls, streams, and lush foliage. While I have no idea what any of it has to do with Nashville itself or its history, it is quite lovely. The strategically placed oversized guitars feel a bit out of place, and yet seem more authentic to the local flavor. Compared to Gaylord Palms in Orlando which actually has decor centered around Florida (Evergaldes, Key West, and Saint Augustine), I felt less of the connection to the city here. However, I can't deny that the hotel is still quite picturesque. Visit around Christmas, and the entire hotel is bedecked in holly and strings of twinkling lights as well.

Like any major hotel, Gaylord Opryland  comes with its pros and cons. The parking is high on my annoyance list, because although it is ample, it is pretty steep extra on top of the cost of your actual room. Whether you are a short term visitor, or a hotel guest, expect to pay around $32 a day. Also the restaurants are plentiful (think Italian, Mexican, sushi, and a grill), but none are particularly great. They do have Starbucks on premises if you are short on time, but walk or drive across the street to Nashville Coffees for a better selection and more interesting options.

If you are staying on business or at the hotel for a conference, the conference center is massive and quite convenient. There is more than enough space for an exhibition hall and smaller rooms for more intimate talks. WiFi is available throughout the area if you need to sneak away to get work done on your laptop. Speaking of the WiFi, you can also connect throughout the grounds or in the hotel rooms, and they have a direct wired connection if you need something faster, which makes a better choice if you need to connect to a VPN or are on a call.

The rooms themselves are comfortable, although certainly some sections are better than others. For example, a room in Magnolia may have you in a fairly basic look (your standard outdated hotel) and a view of a courtyard/pool, whereas in Delta the rooms seem to be a bit more modern, and if you're lucky you can get a view of one of the domed areas, which makes for great people watching.

Worth visiting at least once, even if you aren't a hotel guest! At the very least make a stunning venue to get some steps in...

This is a small, cozy bar, with, I think, three floors.  I've been here four times, and each time has been a good experience.  The mac n' cheese is amazing.  It's very close to going on that list of foods that I'd want at my last meal.  I had the bangers n' mash the last time I was there, and was extremely happy with them.  The pork sausages were perfectly cooked, and packed with deliciousness.\n\nService is good, and the only reason I dinged them a star is that their beer selection is really, really small.  They're not putting on airs about being a world class beer bar, but frankly, they're just lacking in this department.  They've got Guinness, and a couple other good beers, but six or seven beers doesn't really cut it, anymore.  Bump up the draught beer list, or get a decent bottle selection, and then I'll bump you guys back up to four stars.

I hate to do this, because I absolutely HATE the Phillies, but this is a nice stadium.  The layout is perfect for watching the game from your seats, hanging out in Ashburn Alley, or just wandering the concourse.  The food is generally pretty good, though it has gotten MUCH more expensive since the ballpark opened back in 2004.  I'm sure that has to do with the success of the Phillies in the past couple years, and their string of sold-out games.  Chickie's & Pete's has a couple stands here, and many of the concession stands sell quality beer, not just the standard BMC swill.

Back when I was in college, and, surprisingly, had more money than I do as a hard working engineer and homeowner, I used to go to tons of games here.  I actually think I went to every Mets-Phillies game in 2004 and 2005, and there really aren't many bad seats in the house.  I very much miss the days when the Phillies were awful, and the Mets were pretty good (and I still blame Carlos Beltran for missing that Wainwright curveball in the 2006 NLCS).

The biggest issue I have now is that you can't tailgate in the majority of the parking lots.  You've now either got to park behind Jetro, which is shady as hell, or in the Holiday Inn parking lot, which fills up almost immediately.  Otherwise, I think the only other stadium I've been in that's nicer than CBP is US Cellular Field in Chicago, where the White Sox play.  Admittedly, I haven't been to many of the newer parks on the west coast or to the new Yankee Stadium.

I love everything about Tutti Toscani.  The food is better than any other Italian place in the area.  Pizza is great, though it's a small selection.  The appetizers are good, and like Meghan C. said, you can't go wrong with the antipasto.  All the veggies are fresh, and prepared perfectly.  The meats and cheeses are great, as well.

As for entrees, I've had probably ten or fifteen different dishes, and they're all great.  They usually have some really good specials, as well.  They do a LOT of seafood, and many of their seafood dishes have lump crab meat on them, and believe me, it's a TON of crab meat.  Prices are really good...I think the most expensive dish I've had here was like $25, and that was a special on New Year's Eve.

It's BYO, which is great, and Anna really takes care of people.  She's a madwoman, all over the place, but when there's a wait, she's always coming out to the waiting area to talk to people and see how they're doing.  Also, the outside seating area is awesome during the spring and summer.  It's comfortable, there's a nice pergola over your head, and their garden is right there.  It's a great, casual place where you can go and get an honest meal for a good price.  We've gone there in shorts and t-shirts for lunch, or dressed up nicely for dinner on special occasions.

Johnson's is a nice spot to take the kids for any seasonal activity, but jeez, it's a racket, price-wise.  We took my son to do the Easter Egg hunt last week, and for a twenty minute hayride, as well as a three minute search for eggs, it was $16, for two adults and a child.  That didn't get you access to the animal farm area, or to the jungle gym, each of which has signs up that if you don't have a wristband, you'll be asked to leave.

The egg hunt itself was in a grove of trees, and they basically just took a couple hundred eggs of different colors, dumped them in the trees, by color, and told the kids to grab one of each color, then get their prize back.  Nice, but $16 nice?

The animal farm area looked nice from behind the fence, as did the jungle gym, but I'm not sure that they were worth paying the extra cash to get in, especially when there's a park with a huge jungle gym just a couple miles away.

This place was a fine bar.  A little hipster-ish, but the beers were semi-decent (albeit low ABV and not very varied), so I'll forgive it.  The crab cake sandwich that a friend ordered looked pretty awesome.  The service was great, and I didn't have to use a flare gun to flag down anyone or feel like I was being a pain by asking for another drink.  \n\nThe one really weird thing was that every time someone played a song on the jukebox, it was SUPER SUPER loud for the first five seconds, then you couldn't hear it anymore.  I'm not sure if someone behind the bar was turning the music down, and had to do it each time a song was played, or if their jukebox was broken, but it was pretty lame.  I actually got to the point where I wouldn't talk when a song ended, because I wanted to wait until the onslaught of obnoxious (mostly hipster) music was over.  Once they'd turned the music down, though, you couldn't hear anything, which was bad for the ambiance.

Until we found the Ritz, this was our go-to place for movies.  It's pretty bad.  Getting in and out is tough, due to the entrance/exit situation on Haddonfield Road, prices are high, and whenever you go, it's nothing but unruly kids throwing stuff and screaming.\n\nI can NEVER get my wife to go to the movies, so I've resorted to going to Friday afternoon matinees by myself, after getting out or work early.  I've even stopped going to those because of the clientele that frequents this place.

We bought my wife's used Mercedes C280 here back in 2009, and the dealership was nice inside.  They tried to kill us on the price of the car, and misadvertised it, saying that they always post the online price of a car, assuming a $3,000 down payment at purchase.  So, the car that was advertised on Cars.com for $24,000 is really $27,000, but there's nothing on cars.com that says that.  We nailed them, and they agreed to give us the car for $24,000.  Then, they tried to screw us big time, by saying my wife's Mazda was worth half the KBB value.

We should have walked out then.  We didn't.

We sat and negotiated, and threatened to leave many times, but they came down to a monthly payment we were happy with, and we bought the car, but told us they couldn't service it, and wouldn't honor any of their complimentary oil changes, since it was a Mercedes.  All in all, we were at the dealership for probably five hours, and didn't leave until well after 11 PM on a Friday night.

I have two specific problems with them, though.  They were more interested in telling me how great they were because they'd just sold a GT-R to an Eagles player (and I hate the Eagles).  The second is because they hired Michael Vick to be their spokesman.  For that, and that alone, I'll never go to Woodbury Nissan again.

Had waxing done by Raine during a visit to New Orleans. She was professional, made me feel completely at ease, and did a great job. She also seemed very straightforward and down to earth, in a friendly way... like, if you didn't feel like making mindless small talk, you wouldn't need to, cause she's just doing her job, but if you wanna chat, she's also happy to do that. Basically, the type of esthetician you want!\n\nI really liked the vibe of the place, too - super welcoming, NOT a bunch of over-manicured people staring down their noses at me as I rushed in with minimal makeup and with my hair still slightly wet. It also seemed like an efficient place, where you can get in and out and on with your life if you're just looking for a quick service (although I'm sure they could do pampering if that's what you're looking for, too. I was just there for the waxing).

Loved the live band on Saturday night! The trumpeter in particular was phenomenal at both trumpet and singing. As others have noted, this is around the corner from Bourbon Street and much classier than anything you'll find there.

I needed to use my groupon deal before it expired so we came here on a Friday night.  I guess a lot of people bought the deal bc there were tons of signs by the entrance advising to tell your hostess if you're using the deal & that you would have to pay in cash (are they allowed to do that?)

Regardless, they were super friendly and welcoming.  The set up itself is strange & def needs an upgrade.  The decor seems like it should be on one of those restaurant makeover shows.  There's tons of space but the layout is awkward & I felt like I was walking into someone's poorly decorated living room.

We started off with the chicken satay & crunchy shrimp rolls -- not so great.  The shrimp roll was 1 shrimp on a skewer with egg roll wrapping around it & deep fried.  The hot oil oozed out after my first bite.  I had the drunken noodles were just a hot mess & the bf ordered the Royal Rama chicken - which was just chicken & tons of sauce.

extremely nice service & good thai iced tea but mediocre food =(

When you first step in, it's a little off putting because it looks like Dracula's love den with the dark lighting, chandeliers, and dried dripping wax.  Once you look past all this, they have am extensive selection of beers and cocktails, ample bar space, and picnic style tables.

I tried the $5 st. Germain cocktail which was delicious -- highly rec getting it if you don't want the beer. Service was super friendly and knowledgeable.  The only odd thing was that they closed the tab on our table of 8 but said if we wanted anything else, he would reopen it & apply a 15% discount.  Mind you, we didn't ask for the bill so we were a bit confused?? 

I had the special $5 burger.  Looked delicious but very small.  I wolfed down the vinegar dressed burger in 5 bites and I take tiny bits!!!  The fries kept me busy for another 2 bites but then sadly, my plate was completely empty.  Someone else got the hot dog dressed in cheese & bacon but it was still a regular small Nathan's dog hiding under tons of calories.  I'm going to give them the benefit of the doubt that their regular food items are better than these specials.

Unique atmosphere & good drinks, it's worth a try.

Finally had the chance to try out this place & I will def be a regular customer now.  Amazing selection of hot dogs that are absolutely loaded with toppings & reasonably priced.  

I wasn't feeling too hungry so I had the Fiesta dog which came on a hearty & toasted bun, guacamole, lettuce, tomatoes, & sour cream.  It was filling and fresh -- felt healthy w/ all the toppings.  My bf had the Bronx Bomber & Cincinnati Skyline which he enjoyed.  I was jealous when I saw the skyline bc it was loaded with cheese & chili.  We shared medium fries with the sweet pineapple sauce, chipotle mayo, & rosemary garlic.  Choosing those sauces was difficult bc they have 20 or so.  

Staff was great too -- super friendly & welcoming.  They happily bring your food over to your seats.  The only thing is that I wish there was more seating.  There's only 3 long tables & it's a popular spot so it can get cramped in there.

I've been passing by this restaurant frequently ever since it opened and I have always been curious to see how it was.  I'm glad I finally have!

Decor - really spacious & nicely decorated.  nice restaurant/bar atmosphere especially with the live music - cool vibe.

Food - For appetizers, we tried the oysters, the sausage flat bread, & crab cakes.  The oysters were large and juicy but didn't have much flavor to it.  The sausage flatbread had good toppings but we felt that the bread should have been crisper & less soggy.  Crab cakes were delicious!  The kettle chip crust on the crab cake was so good!  For entrees, we had the salmon & fried chicken.  Fried chicken had hints of old bay seasoning infused into it.

Overall, I really like the atmosphere of the place & will definitely come back.  I want to try the drinks next time!  The waiter also told us that they are changing the menus so they have more of a "southern" touch to their foods.  Some of those new additions are the catfish & fried chicken.

Rainy Sunday & I didn't feel like venturing far for brunch so we stopped by to try Twisted Tail again.

It was empty (prob due to the rain) but their brunch menu has a nice selection.  There are usual choices like pancakes but they also offer their specialties like crawfish mac n cheese, crab cake sandwich, buttermilk chicken...

I had the breakfast burrito (eggs, bacon, pulled pork with sweet/tomato-y sauce).  It was ordinary to me & not much better than one I could find at a deli.  My bf ordered the steak & eggs -- very disappointed.  The steak was very dry with no accompanying sauce & the eggs sunny side up were slightly off.  Err...I liked the fries though!

Okay & overpriced food but I would only come back when there's no where left to go.  They do draw quite the crowd for their live music.  Also -- free buffet on Wed nights if you eat at the bar!!

Very very impressed by my stay at Best Western. Although this was the most I have ever paid to stay at a Best Western, this is also the nicest Best Western that I have been too. The rooms had a very big layout, there was complimentary bottled water and fruit. I was on the bottom floor so my door faced the parking lot, and the sliding glass door faced the pool. The pool area was well maintained, the grass was healthy, and lots of beautiful plants. The only unusual thing about the hotel was the windows in the bathroom. The windows were high so people could not see in, but they were slated glass so you could hear everything outside. Although this is on the opposite side of downtown, I would stay here again if the price was right.

My neighbor and I were starving after exploring the French Market and decided to stop here b/c it was rather empty so we assumed we would be able to get food fast.\n\nThe service here is horrible.  The wait staff is slow, the food takes forever to come out, and the prices aren't that good.  I have never had to wait so long for a BLT...such a basic sandwich to make.   Plus it was 11am when we were eating, not a major meal time, I would hate to see how long it would take to get your food when it's actually busy.  Thus I would recommend avoiding this place at all costs.

Amazing warm chocolate nut cookie when you check in, and they gave me another when we left. Super comfy bed, I wanted to go out and buy one for my house. I loved the Crabtree Evelyn bath products. Great location downtown, there was a subway stop directly outside the hotel. The only other strange thing was that our room was located by the ice machine, I have never heard such a loud machine. It sounded like a glass table was crashing outside our room every half hour. Overall great location/hotel/room but no free wifi, so minus 1 star!

I couldn't have been more excited to stumble upon this darling wonderland on our humid explorative trek around Nashville.

I felt like we were experiencing a sliver of San Francisco at Kellie's healthy delectable oasis. I especially appreciated all of the gluten free options on her menu. I don't have a gluten allergy, but i always find myself having an easier time digesting things, when things happen to be gluten free.

Our first meal here we had the  Mediterranean Vegetarian Sandwich (sans feta cheese) on fresh Gluten free bread - consisting of eggplant, roasted red pepper, sun dried tomato, and freshly made pesto, and the Spinach Salad (sans feta cheese) consisting of spinach, dried cranberries, sliced almonds & balsamic vinaigrette. Kellie even went out of her way to replace the feta cheese with some additional vegetables like tomatoes and cucumbers. Both were excellent, reasonably priced at $6.00-$7.00 and you could taste the love embedded in each. We washed down both with A Matter of Taste's cold refreshing fruit tea.

We were so impressed with our experience at A Matter of Taste that we decided to venture out here again the following day. We decided to try their regularly rotating lunch specials. We went with the Pumpkin Brittle and Watermelon adorned salad, as well as their Fish Tacos. The salad was outstanding. A Matter of Taste makes their own salad dressing and you could tell. The fish tacos were also very flavorful. 

A Matter of Taste's eating area is intimate, but if you take a look in the back you can see their sprawling immaculate kitchen where all of the magic happens.

If you're looking for quality and healthy food for reasonable prices - A Matter of Taste is outstanding. I recommend them wholeheartedly. My only regret is not sampling one of their gluten free desserts - ranging from moist looking cupcakes to large rockin' cookies.

Trust.

Bliss.

Absolute bliss.

Thanks to Katie B's gushing recommendation - we joined her, Farrah A, and Tomas R at Bacchanal for the most delightful afternoon - full of chilled rosé, stunning cheese plates, and beautiful music. 

Sitting in the comforts of the shade beneath elegant overhanging trees - while beaming faces - enjoyed the enclosed oasis of fantastic wine and wonderful company - I felt abundantly thankful.

Bacchanal is worth the Uber ride. It's non-pretentious, full of great vibes, and it's always graced by lulling live music.

I recommend coming on the earlier side- since I've heard it does get busier later on in the early evening. But definitely don't sleep on this New Orleans gem. You could easily spend all day here.

Trust.

Visiting from out of town and looking for a unique cafe for breakfast and to do some computer work, I happened upon this gem (with Yelp's help).  Warm, welcoming atmosphere and employees and great food.

I wish I had looked at these reviews before bringing my car to the Collision Repair center for service.  After leaving my car there for one week, I received it back with only half of the work done.  There evidently was a dispute over what the repair center and what my insurance company were supposed to do, and it does appear that my insurance company bears some responsibility.  My primary concern is that when I spoke directly with the person at reception about having the repairs done, she neglected to tell me that there was a problem and that she needed additional information. Instead she told me everything was all set. I think she was overwhelmed and just wanted to move on to the next waiting person.  A week later, after having been told the car was completely repaired, I went to pick it up to find only half the work done - and, had to find this out myself.  No one at the repair service told me that they only did one part of the repair.  Poor, expensive, assembly-line service is what you will get at this place.

Review Update:
As Shawn at Don Brown mentioned, after posting this review, I was immediately contacted by Pam in Customer Service.  Everything Shawn said is correct.  Pam handled things very professionally and discussed concrete ways they will implement to make the service experience more helpful and supportive of the customer.  I appreciated her call and realized that I had I requested to speak with her or someone in the Customer Service area, much of yesterday's frustration could have been alleviated.  Lesson learned.

This place is legit!! The oyster pancake was just like the ones I had when I was staying in Taipei.  All the food was amazing! I highly advise anyone and everyone to come here.  Service was fast even with a packed house, the food came out quick and almost all at once.  For good fresh food in the down town area come here!!

So came here with a group after a long weekend looking for pho after partying, sadly it was not the pho we needed.  Compared to other pho spots the bowls were small, prices high, broth bland, tendon undercooked, no fish sauce, tea was an extra fee, the combo came with 1/2 a beef ball!!!! Add to this it took about 30 minutes to get all this to arrive at our table.

We were heading to the Indy Fringe theater for a show on Tuesday and stopped down for a quick bite to eat before. What a great choice by my friend (and former student. We taught her well!).

A cute little patio and great English-style tables inside. The servers were quite kind. Our drinks were filled always. 

The food was so-so although for a pub, the menu is pretty robust. 

Definitely going to be on my places to hang out when I'm looking to hang out at places.

This was the first stop on my South and Southwest camping trip. I specifically chose the KOA because I knew I could mess things up and they would be helpful.

Indeed they were. (Even as I set up my tent in the torrential rains that hit.) The facilities were first rate: clean showers, bathrooms, and a great little kitchen and washing machine area for those funky clothes days.

It's KOA: so you know there were about a billionty things for kids to do. The best part: directly across from Opryland. If you don't get why that's the best part...put down the computer, back away, and then run.

It's a bit out of the way for my trail running -- about 20 miles -- but definitely worth the stay.

The only annoyance: the campground lights sit along the tent grounds, which means there is a stream of light that you need to block out with the rainfly, even when it's not raining.

In the last few months, I've randomly met some friends. While they didn't know each other, I thought they'd all get along smashingly. So we decided to meet at The Wellington.

(To avoid suspense, the night was great!)

My friend and I couldn't find the entrance for the pub. It's connected to The Corner Wine Bar. You can either enter through the main seating area for that place OR you can go around the corner, through the little side door. Sounds easy. It's really not.

Once you're in, though, The Wellington is a cool place. The bartender came to the back and served us. I'm not sure if that's normal when it's busy (I suspect not), but she was amazingly cool to us.

The only down side to this place: it's smoky as hell. I hate to be the douchey ex-smoker, but alas, I am exactly that. The room is so small that the smoke permeates everything. Be ready for that.

Otherwise: totally chilled out place, to paraphrase David Brent.

I'm a coffee shop junkie so stumbling across this place in the morning before I headed to the airport was fun. 

I didn't check out the Wiki (I'm told there is Wifi), but the handful of people on their computers suggests that it exists :) The espresso was good. Always a bonus. It's hard to get a solid cup of coffee.

The barista was a bit over-caffeinated, but these things happen.

I can't wait to head back, hole up for a bit, and see what working in this place is like. It wasn't very crowded during the day, for sure.

I love this hotel.  I was there there last weekend, and last month... at their restaurant to scope the whole place out for an upcoming event/intimate meeting. I usually do Hotel Monteleone  but Aces popped out to me because of their hipster feel (which is exactly what I've been looking for!).  Room was cool and was barely able to strum some chords on an acoustic guitar but reminiscent of my earlier years. Loved the menu at their restaurant and... absolutely loved "Church".   His service, quick wit and charm made my colleagues and I's evening at the bar. And while our servers have always been great at Aces, Church was the one who made us feel at home and welcomed. He was a quick friend to us. Not pretentious. I went up to the bar, asked for something unusual and he went out of his way more than expected. We wound up staying longer because of him. Talk about CX when we are writing about a white paper on customer experience. I would definitely use Aces for an upcoming event as long as Church was there making sure things happen. He is a gem and so is Aces. Thank you

Super disappointed. Came back to possibly host a banker event at Ace and found out that they had let their best person, " Church" go. This Gen Z manager was so full of their ego they totally missed what good customer service is all about. Not listening to my needs. Expecting me to bed over backwards. Whatever. If anyone knows where "Church" went or where I can find exceptional service, please DM me. It never ceases to amaze me how much egos get in the way. I am so disappointed in Ace's poor decisions as management has no clue. \n\nCan I give them less than one star?

Love Flanagans!

Some of the beat bar food. Great crowd.  Fun to have the ghost tours for those of us outsiders.  And....the couple of times I've been there I've had a serious crush on the bartender, Church.  

Not a place to miss if you're living in or visiting NOLA.

Philadelphia is gritty, from the surroundings to the people. Phillies are dedicated fans and it defiantly showed. They came out hours before the game and sat in the rain til it started. We watched the Phillies vs the Washington Nationals on Monday, May 21st. It was funny routing for the Nationals the day before. We arrived over two hours early and they had already opened up a limited section of the park. We got a drink at Harry The K's the restaurant in left field named after Hall of Fame broadcaster Harry Kalas. You can sit and watch the full game there as long as you keep buying. We watched the Phillies batting practice and walked around the park as it opened. We had seats on the very top level (4 levels!) and it was high up there, still a great seat...but almost a touch of vertigo. The whole stadium felt huge. Capacity 43,651, but it felt like 50+

The video board in left field was so clear and massive, apparently it's the largest HD screen in the National League.  It also wouldn't be Philly without a replica Liberty Bell.  It "rings" and lights up after Philly home runs and wins. Unfortunately, we didn't see either. The Nats won. Another Philadelphia quirk is that their bullpens are in the outfield amongst the fans. When they first opened in 2004 the Phillies bullpen was closest to the fans and after Philly fans booed their own pitchers (these are the same fans that booed Santa Claus) they switched to have the visitors section closer for heckling.

The mascot always needs mentioning. Its rates high on my husbands list. The Phillie  Phanatic....a green beakish creature. The Phanatic has been named the best mascot before and he did not disappoint. He was absolutely hilarious. He came out with a full rain suit on when it began to sprinkle. He mimicked and danced with middle school cheerleaders. There are also videos of him traveling to the Galapagos Islands...his birthplace.

All in all, the stadium might not have a beautiful backdrop of the city, but it was still a beautiful park.  Its very open and you can see the game the entire time you walk around the park.  There were so many options for food (love the cheesesteakes!) and the craft beer was endless. You had to search for any macro beers if you wanted. We were highly impressed with the Philly beer scene.  Philly really was a passionate town about its sports, beer and food.

Quick and super friendly. Emily was super helpful with our order. The burgers were cooked just right and our order of fries and onion rings were just the right amount of crisp. Overall, this was a great experience.
Total jerks - completely rude to our large group and openly mocked us to our faces. We left immediately. I've never been so insulted - do not go here.

I wasn't feeling well... and if I had my choice it would have been a matzo ball soup type of night. Or I may have just skipped dinner and gone straight to bed, but felt like I needed to eat something while pregnant. 

My colleague and I opted for dinner at Wildflower Grill, conveniently located within the Matrix Hotel we were staying at. We made our way downstairs and were seated immediately (no reservations necessary on a Tues night).  

By no fault of Wildflower Grill, but thanks to my stuffed up nose, there wasn't much on the menu that sounded appealing, but I finally settled on a caesar salad. And of course I couldn't pass up on ordering the bread appetizer that so many yelpers raved about.  Both hit the spot, especially the very warm bread that practically melted in my mouth.

I'm sure there's even better food on the menu that my bread and salad, but I"ll have to wait until my next trip to Edmonton when hopefully I'm feeling 100%.

Thank you Comcast Wall for keeping us entertained for 3 hrs while working the check-in table at the fabulous Yelp Spring Feastival. Fortunately, the Philadelphia yelpers are one cool bunch so getting bored wasn't a problem, but when have to sit at a table for 3 hrs staring at a wall of a building it's pretty awesome if there's a show occurring right on that wall.\n\nThis is one cool wall! You'd think I'd be sick of watching it after 3 hrs, but not so much the case (maybe just a bit dizzy).  I do still question the tourists I watched stare at the wall for several hrs at a time. Yes, it was a rainy day in Philly, but surely there's cooler stuff to do than spend a day staring at a wall even as awesome as this one.

Traveling with a bad cold is not fun...I was totally that person full of germs that I typically avoid on planes. Fortunately once I arrived in Edmonton (after passing my germs to everyone on the plane) the Matrix Hotel provided me with a clean spacious room and a comfortable bed so I could get a little bit of rest during my short trip.

Overall, I liked this hotel and wouldn't definitely stay here again. My colleague and I were in town to do interviews and they have a nice lounge upstairs that was the perfect spot for them (and it helped that it was empty too). 

It's also centrally located near lots of restaurants, shops and more...so there's no need to rent a car in what I believe is typically a driving city.

The restaurant downstairs was also solid if you happen to visit during one of Edmonton's infamous cold winters.

3.50 stars.  

Gabby's wasn't open.  I knew that.  Neither was Rotier's.  But my handy Yelp app had assured me that Fido's was open.  Imagine the disappointment when I realized there was a very real possibility that no burgers would happen on this trip down to the Deep South.  Would I really have to wait two more weeks when I would find solace in East Texas?   

"We can try Burger up," I mentioned.  

"Why don't you just call them?" hissed the appropriately nicknamed Viper.  

True.  We didn't have to keep driving around aimlessly.  So I call Burger Up, and a very pleasant, sweet voice assures me they are indeed open.  

Viper: "What was her name?  She sounded hot."
  
Me: "Paige."

Viper: "Yeah, she's definitely hot.  Have you ever met an unattractive Paige?"

Me: "Good point.  At least we have that going for us."

Paige was indeed attractive, but this review isn't about a photogenic individual who happens to work at Burger Up.  It's about what ended up being a visit to our fourth choice for burgers in Nashville.  

Burger Up follows a national trend towards upscale burgers.  My particular order consisted of a medium rare patty served with aged cheddar, Benton's bacon (very good), and ketchup served on an artisan bun.  Basically, it was a gussied up bacon cheeseburger, but it was a rather tasty one.  My major complaint is that I wish the actual meat itself exhibited more flavor.  Having said that, the burger was cooked properly and the flavors worked well together.  I ordered some wilted spinach on the side (mediocre) and truffle fries.  Let's talk about those truffle fries for a bit.  I know more people are apparently into the sweet potato fries here, but I think they are missing the boat.  Burger Up's truffle tries have pleasant aroma, taste great, and are the perfect texture for soaking up oil.  If you are on a diet, it is true you should skip these delightful fries.  But if that were the case, why are you at a burger joint in the first place?  Seriously, if you get nothing else out of my review, please do yourself a favor and order the truffle fries.  

Burger Up also boast an interesting beer menu with semi-obscure breweries from the Deep South included in the list.  I tried a pecan-infused amber from Mississippi - not bad.  I could imagine Burger Up could be a decent place to drink for a bit after eating.  

If I attended Vanderbilt, I would probably go here on a moderately frequent basis.  If you want a change from the dive bar hamburger, Burger Up is a decent change of pace.

3.50 stars.  I was told to go here for the shrimp and grillades (grits) and fried chicken, but I ended up loving the gumbo more than anything.  Located in Mid-City, Li'l Dizzy's is a cozy diner serving up an all you can eat breakfast/lunch consisting of fried chicken, trout, shrimp creole, rice & beans, grits, gumbo, omelettes made to order, fruit, and maybe a few other items as well.  It was all pretty standard until I reached the gumbo.  

Li'l Dizzy's gumbo is heavenly.  They don't hold back on either the sausage or the seafood as you have generous cuts of andouille sausage and crab legs in the wonderfully thick dark brown soup.  They got the flavor so perfect I felt no need to add any tabasco to my order.  I'd definitely come back here for the gumbo.  

Overall, you have plenty of options for breakfast/lunch in this city, and Li'l Dizzy's is a good one if you are in Mid-City.  It's a great option if you just want a cup of gumbo.

Quality burgers for very reasonable prices. I am from California so I had no idea what to order and the cashier explained everything me. She was very helpful and and the end of our meal asked us how we liked our food. I ordered the bacon and cheese burger with mayo, tomato and lettuce. The meat is very tender and juicy. The fries are given in bags that are filled with them. I recommend this place as the best burger joint in Indianapolis metro area!  Cheers! Good eats!

i have been going here since 1996, and it gets better every time I go. There is just too much to list, and everything is good. If you are in St Petersburg do yourself a favor and stop by.  My favorite sandwich is the Hot Italian. I also like to grocery shop for pastas, meats, cheeses, beers, wines, bread, coffee, and deserts.
Great place for LP shopping even great for CDs. They have an archive about six blocks away.

Lots of pretty people, great drinks, and a great beer selection. The do also sell food, imaginative small plates. A little pricey, but worth it. Always a great place to people watch for pretty ladies.
I had a decent meal here. The prices were decent and the was great. Comfort soul food all the way. Definitely going back.
Great service, great subs, and award winning cubans. The Chicago beef(Italian Beef) is the best in the area.

This is their archive that holds many thousands of records. They have everything here from Edison cylinders, 78s,45s, and LPs. I can spend hours here. They bring in more vinyl every day. A lot of vinyl is sold over the internet and people come from all around the world to browse through the stacks. They will even let you listen to the record before you buy it. I have been going here since 96.

Simply the best European style beer bar in Tampa. On of the best curated beer selections around, served in the proper glassware. Superb selection of limited release micro brews. What Berns is to wine the Independent is to beer.  Add the great Cafe that has a pear and gouda panini you have a complete evening. Outside seating, cool vibe, cant get enough on this place when in Tampa.

I like the food, the drinks and their wine and beer selections are great. I have been here three times and every time the service by the bartenders has been terrible. I have sat at the bar to watch bartenders walking by you like their wearing blinders. I was not there at a prime time maybe eight people sitting at the bar. The bartender seemed more interested in her conversation with her friend.  This is due to either poor training of the bartender or very poor attitude the bartender. Either one is unforgivable.  Let me help you, if a patron comes to the bar to get a drink and you're busy, acknowledge them so they know you saw them. Patrons will wait longer and be happier(tip better) if you at least acknowledge them. Even if you just make eye contact and tell them it will be just a minute. It's not hard. I wouldn't recommend this place, unless you enjoy being ignored or treated like a second-class citizen.

Bandit coffee is the next step in the evolution of the coffee scene in St Petersburg. The Slayer espresso machine, which is the perfect machine for single origin espressos. They are well equipped to deliver coffee in other forms, pour over,  cold brew, and good old American drip. Pushing five different single origin locally roasted coffees. They deliver without being pretentious or snotty. Minimalist, interior with lots of natural light from the glass wall at the front of the store. Trendy, hipster music and minimal to very little food. Great place to hang with friends for an after lunch coffee.

Authentic Mexican food on the cheap. Nestled in the back of a Mexican grocery store. Great daily specials Pazole soup, gorditas, tortas, and great tacos on home made tortillas.  Not great ambiance but the food and the prices make up for it.

I like this place, great ambience, great food, and reasonable prices. They make everything in house but the tortillas for the nachos. The interior is done really well, almost like an artist owns the place. The staff was excellent as well the service top notch. \n The only hang up I have with this place is really not the restaurant's fault. I went there for lunch and I pulled into the parking lot while talking on my cell phone on a business call(I know I shouldn't do that). While still on the phone I got out of the car and was greeted by someone wanting money. Since I didn't get off my phone and ignored him, he cursed at me so loudly the person on the phone asked where I was at. I made sure to sit inside where I could see my car out the glass block windows. I mentioned it to the staff. Then as I was leaving someone else came up looking for money. I just jumped in my car and drove off while receiving a glare because I didn't stick around to hear what I am sure was a great story of tragedy and need. This place is in a very rough side of town, which doesn't bother me. I would never let my girlfriend go here by herself, especially at night.

The gold standard for ramen in St Pete. They also have Izakaya(think Japanese tapas) and yakitori(small skewers). Killer sake selection and a great mixed drink set up. Whether you just want a bowl of ramen or a full meal this is a great place.

Only someone who understands Cincinnati Chili will "get" this place. If not, they're know for a mild, uniquely spiced chili served on spaghetti with a mound of Cheddar cheese on top. It can be addictive so be careful. Start out with a regular way and work your way up.

Buddy Brew serves the best cup of coffee in Tampa. It's an artisanal micro roaster, and pure coffee house; it's all about the coffee, with simple food choices, some baked goods and poached eggs on toast. The seating is somewhat limited, however, and they have a wobbly table. They do have WiFi. Because they roast their own coffee, you have many choices of beans-- from their espresso roast to single origin roasts. A myriad of brewing methods include: dialed-in espresso, pour-overs, vacu-pots, aeropress, french press, iced and Chemex -- just  to name a few. Give the cortado a shot or try a single origin pour-over and find your bean. If you're looking for frapuccinos or caffeinated milkshakes, keep rolling down the street to Stardookies. However, if you are like me you'll drive past Stardookies and pay little more for a really good cup of coffee.

Great food and excellent happy hour. 
Need to make a reservation but worth trying this restaurant for their seafood and Cajun food. 
I thought they had the best gumbo and jalapeño grits. 
The size was a perfect portion. I'm going back for their burger which looked great and almost everyone ordered it. 

Customer service was good . Couldn't really  tell who my server was but it seemed like everybody helped each other out in the restaurant so flagging down a random server didn't really matter they were happy to assist you.

I last night learned that this place actually has a real store name and isn't just  'the beer store at 9th and Washington" or just "the beer store".  

They have a divided off section that acts as the "bar" in here, and a walk up window where the nice man behind the plexiglass will supply you with whatever beer and/or cigarettes you need.  I've never ventured into the bar section but they do have food off the grill in there, which kind of surprised me.

As mentioned before, the guy who runs the place is really cool and remembers you and what you drink just like any bartender/shopowner would.  In fact, he even complimented me on how nice I looked when I stopped in there wearing a suit for a sixer after getting back from a dry wedding.  Not what I expected to hear at 1:30 in the morning from a guy while buying beer, but it did make me like him a little more.

The other day while I was in there I realized that you can also order a shot at the take out window when you buy your beer, because I saw some other guy do it.  While I probably won't take advantage of this, it's good to know it happens and when I saw it go down I just thought "that's so cool".  Like Wings More is.

I love this place. I visited Philly for my bday and stayed here with my boyfriend. We both loved it especially the walk in shower. We did not want to get out!! 

I adore the modern style and design though I wish there was more of a closet. Bed was comfy and the plug in play was awesome. We plugged up our iPod and portable DVD player and had a ball!

I wish I knew there was a refrigerator in the room because I would have brought some birthday cake!

The bar/ lounge area was awesome. The apple martini's put me down for the night! They also rent out the bar lounge space for parties which may not make you happy if you are on the 2nd floor like I was. Luckily I liked the music and the 2nd night I joined in the fun!!

The price was right and so was the hotel. Definitely give it a go.

Always trying to live up to my "+1 extraordinaire" role, I was Mikey I.'s +1 to his official Uwishunu review of London Grill.  Dimly lit inside, the place tied together almost perfectly the feeling of neighborhood bar and nice restaurant. We both got the customer appreciation 'surf & turf' special ($19 for the meal); Mikey got filet, I got lobster. The special includes a starter salad, entree, and delicious chocolate mousse dessert, and they have $5 glasses of wine to pair with your meal.  All in all it was great food, EXCELLENT service, and a nice atmosphere.

FIVE. I love this place. hands down, LOVE. The only thing I own from there is a couple of cabinet knobs (they have an awesome selection of cool different ones...I think as low as $6 a pop if they're not too ornament). \n\nBut it's just something about the downstairs level that's just floor to ceiling books and plates with little graphic pictures of birds on them, and dishcloths of a thousand colors, and somehow it all looks perfect and you'd just give your left (or non dominant..) arm to have your apartment look like that. Go to Anthro, go downstairs, and experience.

Had a great time here!  Went on a Thursday night for a beer-tasting lesson group sponsored by Budweiser.  Probably half the reason why I loved it so much was because we got free food/beer with the lesson.. but still.. it was great.  The crab fries and wings were outstanding -- best wings that the bf and I have had in Phila.  We also noticed these things that people were ordering called "towers of beer" -- where it's literally a huge tube of beer that they put on your table and there's several pitchers worth in each one.  We already made plans to go back for the bf's birthday because of the great time we had!

Such an amazing find.  I was with Jed S. watching the Hot dog places around America TV show.. and we just had to have some good dogs.  I Googled hot dog places in Philly - and this one came up as winning a "Best of".. so we went.  Great experience - we sat up at the counter on stools.  The dogs were DELICIOUS, and we got free tshirts cause it was our first time there.  I'd def. go back, and get more than one hot dog this time!

If you are going to drop over $200 on a fun night out, you might as well treat yourself to an amazing experience.  Prime 108 is an incredible restaurant.  If it weren't for the influence of country music, I would've thought that I was in some posh LA restaurant.  

The Filet was perfect, the lobster and cheese mac was just like I had it in Boston and the Popcorn chicken was about as far from the KFC version as LA is from Nashville.

Prime 108 is pricey, but incredible.

St. Francis has the last chance mass for St. Louis.  Paired with SLU, their Sunday 10PM mass is packed with tons of college students atoning for the weekend.  The church itself is beautiful.  The priests are fairly orthodox too, despite their more liberal Jesuit background.  The downside is that its really loud before mass.  And despite being packed and having a beautiful choir, the participation during mass is something to be desired.  And they sing "Go make a difference" at the end of every mass.  Worst song ever... hippies...Blech...

I am not a touchy-feely-aura-voodoo-new age type person despite being from California or having Louisiana lineage.  However, this place had a bad vibe.  


The hostess was nice. She sat me, my friend and her dog on the patio. About 5 minutes later she apologizes for the waiter not having approached us yet and stated she would remind him.  Another 10 minutes passed and our waiter charged the table chastising us for having sat ourselves.  I explained that the hostess had sat us.  At that point we should have left.  We still didn't have menus, nor did the table next to us who had been there before we arrived.

The band was fine.  The decor was nifty. The patio was lovely, even at night.

Our server's attitude did not improve, nor did the frequency of his visits to any of the tables.  Parts of our order were missing or incorrect or far from tasty.  My pal had a Mojito assuming it would be fabulous given the name of the establishment.  In fact, that was the only thing that was NOT tasty.  The rest of the meal was tasty enough for her to return the next evening.  She informed me that despite a different wait she had bad vibes and a not so nifty experience but I'll let her review it.

I do not see myself returning here on my next visit.

To quote a wise lolcat, "do not want."

Beautiful restaurant. Small. It was cold OUTSIDE & they kept the a/c on INSIDE? I asked three times to turn off a/c & they said they could not b/c it's from the hotel???Whatever....
The prices are high 
Quality is good
Gumbo was the best I've had so far in NoLa with mussels, Okra & shrimp ....
The shrimp & grits for $24 had 6 shrimp hmmmmm??? It was good but not really better then the S&G I had for 1/2 the price. I was here as 3pm hit and the oysters dropped from $16 dozen down to $6. They were local but not as consistent as ice had elsewhere. Price was AWESOME but I'd rather pay literally a few dollars more for more consistent oysters. 
I really wanted to like the place, but....
The cold bothered us
The waiter never refilled my water even after asking
And he didn't clean my table of Galen food until asked...
Poor service (Alex)
:-((

Pralines!!!!! Sweet!!!!!
no bargains
just very sweeeet food
See fresh pralines being made.
They close early

What it is: A phenomenal place to actually have conversation with people (because you can hear them over the music) and probably the best beer selection in the city

What is isn't: A place to be seen or to pound Red Bull/vodkas (though they are available)

With a simply outstanding beer selection and a helpful, friendly staff, this is a place that bucks the general trend of foo-foo bars and clubs in Old City.  As a resident of Old City, I'm incredibly grateful that this place exists so that I can hide from the popped collars and short dresses (okay, maybe I wouldn't mind seeing the dresses) and the people that wear them that invade my neighborhood on the weekends.  The Irish Pol does what it intends to do very well - provide a low key atmosphere, a knowledgeable staff that will make recommendations on their ever-changing taps and serve it to you with a side of witty commentary.  For the people complaining about the food, I'm not really sure why they're doing so.  The Irish Pol is a bar, it is not a restaurant.  Having fried food available when you're just looking to enjoy some beers is an advantage, not a disadvantage.  

You have to appreciate the Pol for what it is, not what you want or expect it to be.  Is the men's room great?  Nope.  But any guy that complains about the lack of a mirror in there or the general state of the bathroom is probably going to get ostracized for ordering a macro brew anyway and more than likely will not come back because The Pol doesn't have Bud Light/Miller Lite/whatever other watered down brew you can imagine on special.

If you're looking for something low key where you can actually enjoy a great beer with conversation and you don't worry about whether or not you're being checked out, then this is a place for you.

I will never use another florist in Philadelphia. 

I live out-of-town now, so I am unable to pick out flowers in person when I send them back home now.  Thank you, Yelp, for sending me to Pure this year!!  For the same price I spent on an internet florist last year, I got something totally unique, completely incredible, and worthy of my mom!  

My mother received her birthday flowers today, and I was blown away via iPhone photo. I can only imagine just how gorgeous they are in person!  I had asked the designer on the phone to send something bright, oranges and yellows, that exudes happiness and makes you want to do a little dance when you see them.  To be perfectly honest, that is EXACTLY what I did when I received the photo of them.  I'm an only child, so my mom is pretty stoked on anything I do, but hearing the overwhelming happiness in her voice on the phone when she talked about the flowers was next level.  They are absolutely perfect.  I wish I could go hug whomever made them.  THANK YOU!

Seriously, using another floral designer would be a huge mistake/future regret, dear Philadelphia person searching for a florist reading this review.

My girlfriend and I had liked what we'd seen on Sunday's website, especially the menu, so we bought the Creative Loafing deal on it and tried it out. 
The place is simple and comfortable brick wall interior and various Florida artists have their artwork displayed for sale on the walls, which is nice if you really care about that kind of stuff. 
The menu was easy to read and very direct the wine list was short and simple, no cabs was offered, which I did found odd, but they did have a few easy hits like Hob Nob Pinot. 
We were made to understand it changes quite often and is always kept short. Unfortunately, unless you request a bottle to be opened freshly for your glass, you risk getting a refrigerated glass of red.
The warm, soft, herbed focacia and infused olive oil brought to the table is delicious. We started off with the cheese and fruit platter which had nice presentation, was generous and came with even more yummy, warmed breads pita & crostini was the winner of our experience. 
We settled on one of the specials which was a plate full of sea food accompanied by rice and roasted vegetables, since we wanted to share it we added a sirloin to the platter. 
The wine, cheese and easy going atmosphere we were both enjoying, but the main course we found to be a huge disappointment. There was nothing special about the rice i mean it was just rice, the shrimp were over cooked, the ahi tuna was! lets put it this way we didn't eat it, the salmon was cooked perfectly, as well as the large diver scallop, the large stuffed oyster had a strange earthy grittiness and flavor to it,the seasonings were nothing special your straight forward salt and pepper,the platter was very much like the basic fair you get at your average seafood place on Cape Cod,we were fortunately already full from the breads and cheese platter and made due with the salmon and scallop. 
Lastly I will say the place was very accommodating to special requests made by the guest and our server was the other highlight of the experience. 
She was gracious, polite and totally let us enjoy ourselves without being all over us or rushing us. 
I wish I could remember her name, because she was really great. We had high hopes for the place, but unfortunately the food wasn't up to par.
I will give it a next try maybe next  time the food will be on par.

My first time to Let them eat cake.I myself love cakes anyway it's wasnt busy at all, the service I have ever experienced. Granted it was friendly service, after we ordered, it was a few minutes before our everything arrived which was cool. I went from hungry to moving past the pangs of wanting to eat.I must say my cake was good though. The cake we had were ordinary to be honest i  have had better period with a much shorter wait.But its not that bad for me to stay away completey.
